												Rayman Origins is a platform game. A reboot of the classic Rayman game (the 2D one, not the 3D games), Rayman Origins is an excellent addition to the franchise. Rayman and his friends are all relaxing on the Snoring Tree. But their snoring disturbs an old granny from the Land of the Livid Dead. She sends out an army of Darktoons across the Glade of Dreams, who capture the Electoons which inhabit it. You, as Rayman and his friends, must go out across the world and free the Electoons to restore the Glade. Although the story is great, the game's aesthetics and soundtrack is where it really shines. The beautifully crafted world, accompanied by the brilliant musical score, is what really sucked me in. The visuals are absolutely gorgeous, and the soundtrack is superb. Gameplay is excellent too. The animations are fab, and the game overall feels very fluid. I am not a huge fan of platformers, the gameplay usually fails to entertain me, but I absolutely adored Origins. You start off with just the ability to run. But as you progress you unlock more abilities, such as wall-running. There are also certain levels in which you ride a mosquito. You can either shoot enemies or suck them up to fire them. The game comes with 4-player local co-op. This is great, but it would be even better if it included Online play too. This is the only downside to the game. One of the best PC games to be released in 2012. I recommend this to both those who adore platformers, and those who do not.

												Rayman: Origins is a 2D side-scrolling, platforming adventure with full four-player local co-op.Rayman accidentally started a war with the Livid Dead, the monsters lurking beneath the otherwise peaceful Glade of Dreams.The protagonist must work his way through a series of themed stages, collecting floating objects called "Lums", and rescuing critters known as "Electoons" from hidden cages. Reaching certain Lum targets can earn extra "Electoons", which unlock new levels and characters.Besides of jumping Rayman learns new skills such as hovering, swimming and shrinking, bringing a compelling variety to the action, and testing your dexterity to the limits.On your way you have to cross floating platforms, dissolving platforms, platforms that twist and turn, that bounce you into the air or slowly fall and fade.Rayman: Origins has impressive graphics, the backgrounds are beautifully drawn and has multiple layers of action.The levels vary from familiar takes on platforming staples – cloud levels and underwater levels – to such oddities as a world based on didgeridoos.Alongside the standard platforming levels, there are boss encounters, and scrolling shoot-'em-up challenges in which you leap on to a mosquito and fly through formations of angry birds and spiky puffer fish.Rayman Origins features drop-in/drop-out cooperative play for up to four players at a time and as long as one of you stays alive to free injured players from bubbles in which they become trapped when hit, progress through a level remains possible.Everywhere there is humour and whimsy, every screen a feast of bizarre scenery and weird inhabitants.Rayman: Origins is one of the best platforming experiences you are going to have on Steam. The game is crafted with so much love, so much humor, and does so many things right, that it is impossible not to have a blast. 												Rayman Origins is just as the name suggests, a return to the origins of the franchise, which started as a 2D platformer, and also brings back a few of the earliest designs and concepts used in the first Rayman game.I fell in love with Rayman after playing Rayman 2: The Great Escape, and after that, Rayman 3: Hoodlum Havoc.I never actually played the original Rayman more than the first level, i did not enjoy it, i am not a 2D platformer person.But since this year marks Rayman's 20th birthday, i decided to play this game, and wanted to actually finish it, which i did.The game is very enjoyable, even for someone who doesn't really plays 2D platforming games, i can even call it very fun.It has lots of levels, with different themes, and different playstyle to many of the levels, like running levels, where you must be as fast as possible to reach an enemy/cage/etc, there are shooting levels, where you fly on a mosquito that shoots, plain old classic platforming levels, as well as boss fights, which you must avoid the boss' attacks, and then hit him in a weak spot.The engine could use some polishing, but it works just fine, except some parts where you might get stuck on a ledge or stuck inside an enemy, but these are pretty rare and not noticable.The level design is very well done, and requires skill and thought, where you cant just sprint and jump through the obstacles and enemys, and it contains lots of funny and very creative themes to them.As you progress through the game, you gain abilities like flying, shrinking and diving, and you always end up using one or the other after unlocking them, so kudos to Ubisoft for not forgetting that they implement some features and forgetting to actually make you use them.the game took me about 10 hours; 												One of the best platformers I have ever played. The Donkey Kong Country series was the one I always considered the best, until I tried this one. The main thing I like about this game, is that you move at a much faster pace, compared to something like the DKC games. There are optional challenge levels that will test just how good you are at controlling your character at its max speed. If you can complete those, you earn the right to play the Land of the Livid Dead level, which is the most challenging stage in the game. All the secret/bonus rooms in a stage, have their own unique platforming segments that you must get past, in order to get the reward from it. I enjoy that a lot more than how the DKC bonus/secret areas usually are (just collecting the bananas). The boss fights are also a lot more difficult and better designed. The art and animations make the boss fights look so good and those water stages also.The difficulty is also great. Nothing is cheap and unfair. Everything stays the same for a stage and you will never feel like it was the stage's fault for dieing, but your own. The game also has fast respawns for when you die and automatic checkpoints per stage. You will never have to start back at the beginning of the stage (unless you die there) and you will get to keep everything you have collected so far.The game will last you 10+ hours, if you plan on trying to unlock all the levels. If you like this game, then check out Rayman Legends, which I think is even better.

												It's hard not be charmed by Rayman Origins. It has a sort of party atmosphere, with its bright colors, upbeat music, and surreal shenanigans that keep it charming almost all the way. Almost. The graphics are probably some of the sharpest 2d environments seen in a platformer, with a bizarre cartoony look that's not like much else.At its heart, Rayman is a collecting platformer, where you try and collect thingies (lums) to free thingies (electoons), though there's a secondary thingie (skull teeth) you can collect in special challenge levels to unlock another thingie (an extra hard series of stages). As such, if you want to hit every note, you'll be repeating stages to make a better time or to collect more thingies, and your opinion on that may very. Overall, though, you don't have to sweat that too much, and those that can put their collection impulses on hold can charge through the game for the most part.With a variety of moves and skills to unlock, most of the levels become a breezy delight, hovering, running up walls, bouncing off of enemies, etc. In my opinion, it comes very close to dethroning the kings of platforming, save for two issues: the levels can be long, and towards the latter half the game can lean towards being surprisingly tough. Seperately neither of these would be an issue, but together they can deal out some real frustration towards the end of the game. The long levels mean it can lean on being repetitive within a larger world, but each world is varied and often come up with some really great gimmicks, floating through updrafts or sliding down waterfalls. (Note to the developers, though: ice levels where you slide everywhere are not fun.) Annoyingly, the game has a tendency to ask you if you want to switch levels if you die too many times, which it will do over and over - some of the final levels had that pop up occur six or seven times, and when you're just trying to progress, it's rather irritating. An option to turn that reminder off would have been pretty welcome. Contrary to that, though the challenge levels can be similarly tough, their short length and breakneck pace thankfully turn them into one of the highlights of the game. At its best, the game has you charging through areas in a fashion you'd expect of a AAA theme park game, while at no point holding your hand.Ultimately, though, whether you just get a taste or collect every bit, Origins is worth your time. If you can affort Legends, it's a better game that mitigates many of Origins' flaws, but since Origins is often available for just a few bucks during the seasonal sales, it's absolutely worth it. For those with a distaste for UPlay, you can also relax in the fact Origins doesn't use it at all. It's a rare "pure" sort of game from a big developer, with no DLC shenanigans or anti-piracy measures. (This may also be due to the fact it got a government grant for its development...)Give it a shot, you should at least get a smile out of it.

												Everything about Rayman Origins works.   Fastest review I've ever written.  I'm out people! Ok fine you're still here.  Rayman origins is a return to a very old character that never caught on like he should.   Personally I never played the original Rayman games, finding the character just too odd looking when next to Mario and Sonic. But fast forward about 15 years from then, and Rayman origins came around at a time when only indies made simple platforming games.   So is Ubisoft insane, or genius? Well I already said everything about this game works, so you figure it out.  But It really does.  You get the most amazing upbeat music in this game.  It creates a beautiful shiny world, and the world change at just the right pace.    The gameplay is tight, there's no life limit, and the player has a solid challenge with out being too harsh. I mean this game basically has revived my love of the 2d Platformer, a love that so many games have tried to ruin or tarnish since, but Rayman Origins (And the sequel legends) are as close to a perfect game.  There's challenge, but often times it's beyond just beating the level, rather to get some other goal.  It has a wonderful aesthetic.  I mean we're talking vibrant colors and music that are glorious compared to so many games that claim to have great graphics but just go for a dull look.  And then there's characters. As I mentioned before Rayman never caught on.  Actually, I don't know if I ever played as Rayman in a Rayman game, there's so many beautiful colorful creatures who run around, and allow the player to use them.  There's no gameplay benefit to any of the characters, so the player is free to pick the player that they wish. Speaking of different characters, the game also comes with a brilliant four player couch co-op multiplayer.  It's built on the drop in drop out so players can work together.  Now the player can accidently hit each other, knocking them in another direction which can cause death, but at the same time, to get revived, the player can fly around another and any attack or being jumped on will bring the player back. This system works perfectly.  If there's a coin or something for the player to try to grasp, the multiplayer allows the team to have multiple attempts.  There's no penalty for death, and the multiplayer really does work amazingly. I could spend hours raving about it.  There's only really two negatives I have for this game.  The first is achievements.  Or rather lack of them.  In fact the game doesn't implement steamworks at all.  No cloud save support, no achievements for beating the game, nothing.  This is a constant problem I have with Ubisoft's games.  Steam is a wonderful platform, but they have never fully supported it except for a scant few games. The other issue I'd bring up is the Damsel in distress problem.  Now first off I'm not going to claim this is game ruining, and this isn't a deal breaker.  In fact the game can even be said to be perfect, but when I play this game with the daughter, the fairies that the player have to chase and rescue are.. well over sexualized.  scantily clad, and they tend to be large breasted, long legs and "Sexified"Here's the thing, So much of this game is kid friendly, I kind of wish the Faries could be more acceptable.  And while this doesn't ruin it, I look at the warrior princesses of Rayman Legends.   Those are brilliantly designed, and I'm glad that someone noticed this problem.  But it does deserve a negative mention, because it's one of the only things that is perfect for this game. Overall though, with that minor negative out of the way, I'm going to call this game perfect, which means as perfect as one can expect. at 20 bucks this game is great, at less, this game is an AMAZING value.  Rayman Origins produces a kid friendly, challenging platformer, that reminds the player more of a great NES while being as brilliantly colorful as almost any other game.   If you haven't given Rayman Origin's a shot, you should.  It's a fun engaging game, and really I can't ask for more.

												My review will be divided in two parts: in an opinion as a gamer and in an opinion as a fan of Rayman. As a gamer, it is definitely a game worthy of the prizes that received back in 2011 by several identities including BAFTA, as "Best Platformer" and "Best Art Direction". It features more than twenty hours of longevity thanks to its 60+ levels, full of detail thanks to the wonderful job of the artists at Montpellier. It is a breeze of fresh air in the market of platforming games as an alternative to Mario, Sonic, etc. This game also supports cooperative gameplay. Chances are low that you will regret purchasing this, just check by yourself by playing the free demo!As a Rayman fan, I honestly think the game had really a lot of potential to be better than what it turned out in the end. The game suffered significant changes during the development, ending up in something that wasn't quite "promised" back in the E3 of 2010. Keep in mind: "Origins" for the 2D side-scrolling gameplay (like Rayman 1), not "Origins" for the backstory of the most important characters. Don't expect the existence (and especially a coherent) of a story, since this pretty much lacks it. The levels are too linear and easy to overcome  especially if you have a sharp dexterity from Rayman 1. While the artwork is impressive, I think the artists were chosen bad for the background treatment, with just one or two exceptions. For me it is the least good Rayman title out of the four currenty existent, and after finishing it you won't wish to replay it very soon. In short, it is a good game but not as fantastic as the other main titles released before.

Rayman Origins(I also made a video review if you prefer that format)This continuation of the classic platforming Franchise Rayman goes back to it’s origins, as in back to the 2D roots of the first 1995 rayman game.A lot of Origins’ ingredients were already in that first game: The characters, the electoons, even the mosquito Shmup elements!Michel Ancel was responsible for the first 2 (very good and successful) games in the series, and was again on board with Ubisoft when the work on Origins 12 years later in 2011 began.Story and presentationUnfortunately, this game has no story (although one might argue that statement) and does not introduce any of the characters so you either have prior knowledge, consult the manual ( that’s no joke!) or the internet.You are thrown into a cooky world that  looks and sounds great, so much, that it feels like a lovely feverdream on a mix of LSD and amphetamines.The marriage of Audio and Video is wonderfully executed: Music and sounddesign react to what is happening on screen and are always fitting, fun, pleasent, or - if the situation demands it - exciting, and sometimes even a bit eerie. The visuals are stunning and magical and - to me - as impressive as anything realistic or larger than life in modern games.The eclectic Artstyle creates a “big bowl of crazy” and that is what I personally love most about the game!GameplayControls and Leveldesign are on point, tight and fun and  the difficulty is sitting in a nice spot inbetween challenging and almost frustrating.Yes, the game is pretty hard at times. I sometimes found myself repeating one little section of a level a dozen times until I started to get aggravated and cursed at the screen... but It happended rarely and because of a lack of concentration mostly! Every level can be completed by just making it through, or by collecting a certain number of collectibles to get the maximum number of medals for that level. One can also try to beat a certain time to get a speed run medal which is asking for precision platforming.Then there are the crazy treasure chest runs which are levels in which you chase a treasure chest and have to be as fast as possible.These levels require a lot of practice and trial and error progression which could bother many, I liked them and found myself more frustrated with some of the standard levels and bosses... but that might be a question of individual taste.I beat the game in around 11 hours and it will give you at least 15 to 20 hours of gameplay if you target 100% completion.I personally felt the game was a little too long, halfway through when you think you have completed the game, 4 new worlds pop up with a boss in each of them, these bosses are mainly fun but can get a little frustrating sometimes because of trial and error pattern learning on the players part.The leveldesign got better the further you progress in the game, I felt, but still it seemed a little stretched for my taste and schedule but most people would probably disagree.ConclusionIf you like challenging platformers and the Rayman art style you will definitely enjoy this game a lot!It’s not on par of course with SMW. It’s not on par with Super Meat Boy although that is a bad comparison for many reasons.But it’s certainly the best platformer I played since Super Meat Boy and I will definitely play through the follow up Rayman Legends when I get the chance.Last but not least, the game supports up to 4 player local co-op which is really fun!I would recommend this game (I even gifted my little niece a copy for her 3DS last christmas, so there you go)!

												Please, forgive my bad English.This vote has been one of my hardest decision here on Steam.I was wondering while playing if this game should deserve a thumb up, but there were too many elements that keep me distant from the quick decision.I've played the entire game with a gamepad and solo.I started collecting all the possible rewards, but then I got bored and started to go straightforward.I've also played a lot of platformer games, so I know a bit about them.Graphics is superb, with fascinating animations, 3D effects, shaders etc.Music is super awesome: they change constantly genre and get an amazing atmosphere although the strict change of setting in place.Also, performance and the stability (even if I had 9/10 bugs during the playtime) of the game is a great point in favor.The thumb up is due exclusively to this "bright side" of the game.Now, this is an awesome title. There is a big budget behind it, people that liked it (as it seems, a lot of people), and an unending list of people that worked on it.It is evident how great has been the work behind this title, but still I didn't get why developers decided to develop some strangely annoying mechanics.So, here are my impressions about the "dark side" of the game:1) The game environment is unfair:often, especially during the running part and when the scene dynamically changes its structure, there are a lot of unpredictable dangers that, considering the low field of view and the speed of the dangerous object, you haven't the time to avoid them.This is the true motivation on why this game is a "frustration game": you must die several times to know the level and then trespass it (and that's why I started avoiding all the collectibles).There are, also a lot often, enemies that don't act like they do normally but follow a pre-decided path, and often that path is unpredictable and hard to avoid when running or jumping.2) That heart is mostly unuseful:Do you remember when platformer's characters had lives?Just to make an example, in Spyro and Crash there was the possibility to have 3 chances before dying.The choice of giving to players just one chance before dying is not incorrect. It is nonsensical if the hitbox of the character reactivates after half a second, so you have no time to understand how to save the situation.3) Hitboxes of the character, enemies and dangerous environment is not clever at all.There are tentacles that hit you far under the bottom of the drawing and far under the upper; thunders that have a giant invisible hitbox; enemies that I still don't know how far to hit them.Drawings are very pleasant to see but deceive you from their true collision box.4) The controls and the physics are not good for a platformer game: Maybe, here it'd be appropriate a "last but not least".Now, I know that lots of people agree that controls are very good and movement are precise and the overall physics is cool.I think here, maybe, is just a matter of opinion, but at least I want to give a reason to my opinion.Movement is super smooth, even when not on ice, even when you are in the middle air, and this makes it very imprecise when jumping on platforms.Running movement is ambiguous: you can start fast and get your movement even more slippery especially in the middle air when you have no more chances to strike a floating platform.Jumping is decided by the time you press the button, but it has only two values, a high jump and a not-so-short jump, that does not give you the possibility to jump quickly between platforms while running.When becoming tiny, all the physic changes and gives you a very hard time: lateral attacks are always charged, jumps are even more not precise and you are like constantly on ice.Gliding with you hairs almost instantly cut down your speed to a constant value, that you can adjust but still with slippery controls. Also, you can't instantly reactivate the gliding, making the flying parts very painful.Running on curved walls seemed a cool feature, but there are too many parts in wich you must jump to another wall and continue running. I never understood that system as more of half of the times the character started falling down or going backward (on upside-down running).Without any doubt, this has been one of the most slippery platformers I've ever played since years and those 4 points are why the game should have deserved a bad vote.Anyway, the work with graphics, music, humor and cuteness saves this game.And now, let's install Rayman LegendsUpdate:I'm playing Rayman Legends and it's absolutely 100 times better than Origins!All the negative aspects of this title are wiped away, collectibles are fun to take and movements are very precise.

												Rayman has been around since the mid 1990s but the rapid success of the spin-off Raving Rabbids had left the main character behind and stuck in the background. But then one day, original creator Michel Ancel decided to bring the character to give the team a break from developing Beyond Good and Evil 2.The return of the character as well as its return to its platforming roots has been very much celebrated. This is probably as good as platformers are ever going to get. The game has a fun, cartoony look and atmosphere to it, it doesn't take itself seriously at all and it completely blows away anything Sonic and Mario have done over the last 10 years.The difficulty is spot on, no lives system here you just keep going, with checkpoints that are places so the game remains challenging without being frustrating, you'll never be wasting more then a minute of your time getting back to the point where you messed up.The level environments and music are so well created its surreal. You can revisit any level you want to play from the game menu and the flow of the levels are so smooth. The game is long too, expect it to take a good 10 hours to get through, if you pace yourself.Highly recommended if you love great platforming, wacky fun humour and a great art style to fit it all together with. No DRM either!

												25/25 Gameplay9/10 Fairness10/10 Sound15/15 Graphics15/15 Controls13/15 Longness 4/10 MultiplayerRayman Origins, the first remake of the Rayman games, is one of the best platformers I have ever seen. Why? Read this test to learn more!First of all I want to talk about the atmosphere. You play in different worlds and their "Dark" World types. The worlds are completly different (Forrest, African, I won't spoiler more...) and have their own music and graphics. You see  Dust flying up in the African styled maps and after a time this even becomes a part of the Gameplay!The Graphics are just awesome. Hand-made worlds create a feeling of really being in the Rayman World. Together with the fitting sounds and music, this creates a very good atmosphere.Also: When I played the first levels of Rayman, it made me really happy. I played and was happy. I even had to stop myself from playing too much, because I did not want Rayman's adventure to go over too fast!Now to the Fairness and sticked with that: The Controls. The Controls are intuitive and easy-to-learn. After some times, you get new abilities, which though do not make the game confusing. You understand them and they stay in your brain.The game is pretty easy if you just want to play it through. You just have to get through the levels with the (sometimes not so many) checkpoints. But if you want a challenge, ok: Collect over 300, or even 350 points in the level, complete it with the best time possible or even find all of the hidden emoticons!Anyways, sometimes the not so good spreaded checkpoints are a little annoying or the unlimate pro times in the time challengers mode. You have to complete the level in a certain time (may sometimes even be 3 minutes!) AND not die AND be as fast as somehow possible. This is sometimes annoying, but I mean: it is optional, so...I already talked about the Gameplay a bit: Different worlds, different challenges, new abilities, time trial,...The most fun though is exploring the level. If you just up in the "wrong" way that you should and then do a bit of this and that...Hey! There is a mini game for an emoticon! And if you try to just go under the collapsing bridge...50 points in a coin! Nice done, Ubisoft!Also, you unlock new characters and racing levels with the emoticons. The characters are just for the optics, but the races are really fun! With the pursuit soundtrack you run behind a running Chest around a collapsing level, split up, come to him again, etc etc. It is just like a much better time trial mode! Anyways, the Longness is not so long if you just play the game through without secrets, time trials and so on. You can be through in 7 hours. If you do the time trials and the other stuff, Rayman can take like 25 hours. This is up to you. For this huge difference there is a minus in the points rating though...The Multiplayer is the only thing I would critise in the game: You may play local Co Op, but there are no Local Co Op levels, and in a time in which everything is connected to the Internet, an Internet Multiplayer is actually a must-have...TL;DR: If you want to play a platformer which makes you happy while exploring wonderful levels with atmospheric music, you should buy this game! Just if you need a Multiplayer at all costs though, you should think about getting the game.

												Rayman Origins looks and plays really well. It's a great platformer. But...I'm in two minds about this one. And that's mostly due to the last set of levels I had to go through in the game. Maybe this is picky, but, that last set of levels really tarnished the experience for me. Example - You're running along a scrolling screen type setup with falling debris. Hopping from piece to piece when, you get slowed down for a moment. You get back on track, but, now the debris is further along and you can't reach it anymore. Even though, the edge of the screen hasn't caught up, you cannot recover and die. This is terrible level design as far as I'm concerned.That above example happened so many times and it was rage inducing! In fact, sometimes you could be travelling along that same setup, making no mistakes and suddenly the platforms would slow down or go faster than normal for no good reason. Then it's fall to your death time again. AGGGHHHH!However, as much as I've just written a bad overview above, I'm still going to recommend the game. The above only accounts for maybe 5% of the total experience. That and, I was forcing myself through till I beat it.So, overall, it's a wonderful mix of platforming, shooting and just straight up goofy, cartoony goodness. This and Rayman Legends are really wonderful games for old school platforming. So, check it out if you're into that kind of thing!

												It's a Rayman game (I loved the first one on PS1), it's often good, sometimes great... so why I am so bored when I play it ?Two expressions come to my mind to try to get to describe the feelings i have regarding this game: "Soulless" and "Paint-by-numbers".Many of the levels feel empty. You go from platform to platform, you meet some enemies, but most of them are immobile, or even sleeping. They don't feel like enemies at all, they are not here to hunt you, they don't care about you at all. They completely lack personality. Good platformers have enemies that have an interesting behavior that give them personality. Even Goombas in Mario are memorable with their mean looking eyes. In Rayman, in many cases, that's not the case. It's so bad that sometimes it's hard to tell if something is here to help you or kill you (i made a few mistakes that way).Story-wise it's the same. It's full of holes. After a hilarious 5 min cartoon intro, the game tells you "ok you have to fetch electoons again. Go for it". It's almost like there is no relation to what you just saw with what you have to do. Most of the characters you will meet have no name, and will usually don't utter more than one sentence. Sometimes it feels like there are 2 distinct stories and none of them was completed.That's really disappointing, because technically the game is top notch, with colorful environments and very nice animations. And sometimes, the Rayman's magic is back. In a few levels, (particularly the water world levels), enemies actually have personality, the environments are full of life, and the music nicely complement the action.Nowadays AAA studios have mostly abandoned platformers to the indie scene. So i was happy to get a new Rayman from a big Ubisoft studio. I suspect many of you feel the same.However, I can't forget nor forgive the fact that, after 2 or 3 levels, i usually quit the game because i was bored. Worse, i also used the "skip level" functionality several times when i didn't feel like completing that level right away. That's not things i would get in a good game. I did finish the game, including the awesome bonus level (by far, the best level, and really enjoyable), but i really had to force myself to play many of the levels (particularly the wind world).Sadly, there are too many boring levels where I'm just going through the motions. "Been there, done that", was a recurring feeling. Most levels felt like the 1000th iteration on the same stuff from countless platformers. There are too few memorable/good levels for me to recommend this game.Maybe some of the problems come from the added multiplayer. I only played the game solo, and i guess with friends, it would get more chaotic, but also more fun. Maybe that would alleviate some of the issues i had with the game. It would explain why the levels sometimes feel empty and the enemies are too passive: with 4 players it must already be very hard to get to the end with everyone. But I'm unable to test that theory.PS : For achievements hunters, be warned that the game doesn't include Steam achievements, even though the console versions have them.PS2 : Regarding difficulty. Some reviewers state that this game is the toughest game they've ever seen. That's not my opinion. 2D Platformers have often been challenging games. Considering that fact, i think that Origins is not easy, but it's not hard either. If you just want to see the end, as well as unlock the bonus level, Rayman Origins is way easier than many platformers from the 90s, like the SNES platformers, or Rayman 1 on PS1. It's also way easier than some modern titles like Super Meat Boy. If you're familiar with platformers, you should be able to finish it without issue.Time trials are probably trickier, but i wasn't interested in trying them so i can't give you my opinion on them.

												At it's core, a 2D platformer. A few mechanics beyond running, jumping and attacking are unlocked as you progress - swimming , wall running, flying - however they're mostly only used in the world that you unlocked them in. The combat is very simple, most enemies die in one hit, apart from the bosses which have some originality, but like much of the harder portions of the game, the bosses just need lots of repetition to get muscle memory and knowledge of attack patterns. Each level has a few "electoons", which are mostly quite easy to acquire. The fun part in getting these is in the little challenge each section presents, but due to limited game mechanics, I can't remember any distinct ones.The hard parts, such as bosses and the levels where you chase a treasure chest for a secret *thing*, are like quick time events without the visual cues - and if you're just a moment off even though you made a good recovery, the design of the game forces you to play again, getting a microsecond closer to the speed they want you to get to.The visuals are quite nice, but you only notice them in the calm before the storm because otherwise you're too busy running around or trying to not die, which is a shame. The music was unique, but the loops caused by dying repeatedly mean that any nice melodies are quickly forgotten. The sidescrolling shooter parts are fun and a good challenge, and there aren't too many, which means you can accept that they didn't give the separate costumes (oops, I mean characters) distinctive playstiles. As far as I noticed, even in the walking part of the game, the different characters did nothing either, apart from help you identify you and your friends apart.Without co-op I probably wouldn't enjoyed this game enough to bother going very far. Co-op mechanics were decent and allowed for coordination and teamwork, however guacamelee did it better - in fact, I think Guacamelee did everything better, apart from on incomparable things such as artstyle.tl;dr unless you're a big Rayman fan, play Guacamelee instead.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												I've had Rayman Origins on the PlayStation 3 since it first came out, and it's given me hardly any disappointment. It's a fantastically fun game!There's no need to complain about the lack of a story simply because this game is emulating the good ol' days where it was just about the gameplay and fun and not necessarily about the story.Rayman Origins is a 2D platformer, and the control in this game is very smooth and responsive. The game boasts 60+ levels of awesomeness, and players get new powers from the nymphs as they go along. Yes, you have to win the power of punching and kicking. But that's a callback to the first game! And the third! The levels are differently themed. You will travel through jungles, oceans, mountains, frozen tundras, musical lands and even an infernal kitchen! The game is designed to be relatively easier to just get through, however the game does get a lot harder as you progress. Plus, the major challenge in the game comes from gathering the collectables. Electoons can be found in cages or won by collecting hundreds of Lums, which can be found scattered throughout the level, obtained from defeating enemies or finding Skull Coins. The Tricky Treasure levels provide the second-biggest challenge in the game, as they are frantic chase-the-chest levels where the stage pretty much falls apart even worse as you keep going, and you earn Skull Teeth from these. The boss fights are not as difficult as I expected them to be, but they still provide a good challenge. However, once you complete the game there are a few very interesting twists that I will not reveal. Play the game to find out. :P The hardest challenge, of course, comes from The Land of the Livid Dead, a level that is unlocked after gathering all 10 Skull Teeth.[EDIT: I have played this level, and GOSH DARN IT is it hard! I lost track of how many times I died just trying to complete one section of the stage, but it's a lot of fun, and worth it, too. :) ]But it all gets a lot zanier and crazier if you bring some buddies along! Up to four players can play this game at the same time. I've only done co-op with one friend at a time (I only had 2 PS3 controllers), but even that gets nutsy after a little while. The players have free reign to slap each other without directly hurting each other (however that won't stop you from accidentally launching your buddy off the cliff or into a trap). I have, however, done a whole bunch of friend co-op in the game's sequel, Rayman Legends, and if that mayhem was any indication, you're gonna have a great time with this one!The Windows/OS X port was done pretty well. The only gripe I have is that it doesn't appear to be optimized TOO well, as occasionally it will skip a frame or two. It's nothing terrible, but to me, it's noticeable.Now, people may want to draw parallels to Legends. Is it better? Well... To be honest, I found Legends to be a little too easy. Origins packs more of a challenge from what I could see, and, honestly, I kinda prefer the cartoony art over the more realistic rendering of Legends. And it had an anti-climatic ending that wasn't funny like this on--In fact, screw it. This game is miles better than Rayman Legends. To be fair, Legends has more content, but something just feels...off about that game compared to this one. This game has lots of character, bright environments, upbeat and fantastic music and, well, the entire game is amazing!If you love platformers and/or Rayman, GET THIS GAME. You will NOT be disappointed! As you can see, I had no problem buying another copy of this game, so even if you have this game on a console already, get it for Steam.

The game is quite replayable (as I just noticed myself by returning to the game after some time). You can free 5 Lums in every level, and whilst it is not necessary for game completion to get all these Lums, you can unlock new stuff and further levels by getting them all. It is therefore worthwhile to repeat older levels and look cloer for the cages of the Lums, or collect more points throughout every game.There is not much of a story to the game, as expected maybe of a simple jump and run game, but generally the characters are charming and the environment is so friendly and vibrant that the story is not so much necessary.My only gripe with the game is, that, as a longtime rayman fan, i find myself not recognizing the main character very much. This came as a disappointment to me because I was so used to using this special,personal technique in most of his other games. 												An incredibly solid platformer. Smooth, challenging, and utterly worthwhile. Rayman Origins, unlike most of the games in the series, is in touch with its roots, and recovers the same qualities that made the original Rayman such an excellent game. On the other hand, it isn't trapped in the past - this is no mere nostalgia trip, but its own distinct thing with its own unique playstyle and art style. It's not quite as expansive as the original Rayman, but still rewards exploration. and offers multiple objectives in a given level to make multiple playthroughs worthwhile.Skill-wise,it gets reasonably tricky in the later levels, approaching Super Meat Boy in terms of difficulty. The level design has an excellent sense of flow. It's also pretty imaginitive, and evokes the feel of the original game's setting without copying it. The only criticism I have is that it feels very slightly unfinished in places - missing animations, boss fights that are a bit shorter than expected, a somewhat abrupt ending. Nothing that really hurts the game, one just feels that they could have given it another month or so of polish before release and it wouldn't have been a bad idea. If you're looking for a platformer, this is an excellent choice! (They have the original on GoG.com, too - go check that out if you've never played it!)
